description: If there are answers to the enigmatic puzzle that is Jerry Sandusky, they lie well beneath the surface in Washington, Pa., where he was born.
title: In Sandusky’s Birthplace, Questions of How Well You Can Know a Man
title_page: In Sandusky’s Birthplace, Questions of How Well You Can Know a Man - The New York Times
maintext:
WASHINGTON, Pa. — The Brownson House, the old red-brick recreation center on Jefferson Avenue, was like a hearth the whole community huddled around. Every child played there, one generation after another, bouncing a basketball on an undersize court that had an inconvenient pillar in the middle.
From 1952 to 1985, Art and Evie Sandusky ran the place — the sewing classes, boxing matches, table tennis and all the rest — and it’s fair to say they were widely admired. The couple lived in a small apartment at the top of the building, and they had one child, whose name was Jerry.
Art Sandusky, a great athlete, was a local legend, but Jerry Sandusky became well known across the country — praised as a defensive mastermind for Penn State’s football team; celebrated as a humanitarian who started a charity for troubled youth; and, as of last week, reviled as an accused child molester in a scandal that brought down Joe Paterno and rendered chaos at this state’s flagship university.
“I grew up playing ball with Jerry, a nice guy, a really good guy, and when I see this on the news it’s just unbelievable,” said Bill Lindsay, 68. “You know, he’s an absolute look-alike for his dad, and it’s hard to imagine anyone from that family being a pervert. But it’s also hard to doubt all we’ve been hearing. Old Art is rolling over in the grave.”
